Award.AwardTitle: Theory and Application of Berry Phase Methods in Solids
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

In the last two decades, there has been a growing appreciation that certain mathematical concepts from differential geometry and topology are sometimes central to the understanding of the behavior of electrons in crystalline solids. The electrons are described by quantum-mechanical wavefunctions, and the manner in which these vary with momentum encodes many kinds of information about the solid, especially its electrical and magnetic responses and their coupling with each other. When the wavefunctions become twisted in momentum space, this results in so-called "topological insulator" states, which have been the focus of intense research interest in the last decade. By definition, electric currents cannot flow in the interior of an insulator, but a topological insulator has the unusual property that there are guaranteed to be current-carrying channels at the surfaces. The present research program is designed to further develop the formal theory of such effects, to invent robust and efficient computational algorithms for computing the related properties of solids, and to carry out a computational search for materials displaying new or enhanced properties.

The project will lead to the development of algorithms that will ultimately be implemented in open-source code packages and made available to the wider electronic-structure community. It will also contribute to the development of novel materials that are promising for commercial applications, especially ones involving the coupling of electrical and magnetic responses. Training and mentorship of junior researchers (graduate students and postdocs) will take place, contributing to scientific workforce development.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This research program is focused on the electronic properties of topological insulators or other materials in which orbital currents play an important role. The objectives are (i) to further develop the formal theory of such systems, making use of the mathematical concepts of Berry phase, Berry curvature, and Chern number from differential geometry; (ii) to invent accurate and efficient computational methods for computing materials properties related to these mathematical concepts; and (iii) to use computational methods to identify promising new materials or structures in which these properties can manifest themselves, potentially leading to technological applications.

While much recent work has concentrated on time-reversal invariant topological insulators such as Bi2Se3, the emphasis here will be on quantum anomalous Hall or Chern insulators, axion insulators, and Weyl semimetals, in which time-reversal symmetry is spontaneously broken. While the possibility of the Chern-insulator state was pointed out already 25 years ago, it has only recently been demonstrated experimentally, and that only at low temperature. Strategies will be developed for theoretically identifying possible two-dimensional Chern-insulator states accessible to experimental synthesis, with gaps and Curie temperatures large enough to approach room-temperature operation. A second and overlapping thrust will be on the theory and calculation of materials properties that involve macroscopic orbital currents, including bulk and surface anomalous Hall effects, orbital magnetization, and orbital magnetoelectric couplings. As a cross-cutting theme, computational materials search strategies will be used to identify promising candidate materials and structures that may exhibit the desired topological or magnetoelectric properties, especially including two-dimensional Chern-insulator states at surfaces of normal magnetic insulators and their interfaces with time-reversal-invariant topological insulators.

The project will lead to the development of algorithms that will ultimately be implemented in open-source code packages and made available to the wider electronic-structure community. It will also contribute to the development of novel materials that are promising for commercial applications, especially ones involving the coupling of electrical and magnetic responses. Training and mentorship of junior researchers (graduate students and postdocs) will take place, contributing to scientific workforce development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the last decade, there has been an explosion of interest in so-called "topological" materials in the materials physics community. These are materials in which the electronic configuration is twisted, in a certain sense, relative to "normal" materials. For example, "topological insulators" are insulators in the sense that currents cannot flow in their interior, but that are guaranteed to host current-carrying channels at the surfaces, and "topological semimetals" are materials that are almost insulating, but in which the gap separating the valence and conduction bands vanishes at special points or curves in the space of electron momentum. Such phenomena may have important practical applications, e.g., for the development of materials that conduct electricity with almost zero power loss, or that convert electrical to magnetic impulses and vice versa.

The research carried out under this NSF-funded program has been directed toward several ends. First, we have formulated, developed, and coded new methods for theoretically computing the properties of topological materials. Second, we have used our theory to better characterize and understand the properties of known topological materials, and we have theoretically proposed possible new topological materials with enhanced properties. Third, we have studied the dependence of topological properties on temperature. Highlights of the outcomes of this research are described in the following.

Methods development. The usual method of treating electrons in crystalline solids is to work in terms of electron states labeled by a "crystal momentum." We introduced a "hybrid Wannier representation" that is formulated in terms of electron states characterized by momentum in two dimensions, and by localized real-space position in the third dimension. We showed that this approach provides an insightful method of distinguishing between normal and topological insulators. We also developed this technique so that it could be used to compute properties of surfaces that were previously unavailable to theory, including the "surface electric polarization" (electric dipole density parallel to the surface) and "surface anomalous Hall conductivity" (ability of a surface to conduct in the presence of an orthogonal applied electric field). We also developed methods for computing other advanced quantities such as the "Chern-Simons axion coupling" (related to cross-couplings between electric and magnetic phenomena) and "spin toroidization" (a characteristic of the pattern of electron spins in the sample).

Search for new topological materials. One type of magnetic topological insulator is the two-dimensional "quantum anomalous Hall" or "Chern" insulator. The possibility of such a state was demonstrated experimentally for the first time in 2013, but still at very low temperatures. We have proposed that such a state may exist, and be robust to high temperature, for La or Lu atom films on a CrSiTe3 or CrGeTe3 substrate. We made detailed theoretical studies of several materials that are proposed to be topological semimetals with unusual patterns of nodal loops connecting valence and conduction bands in momentum space. We also predicted the bulk and surface properties of potential axion-insulator states, which are magnetic systems with topological properties protected by inversion symmetry.

Variation with temperature. Most first-principles calculations of electronic structure, such as those discussed above, correspond to the case of absolute zero temperature, where the vibrations of the atoms are not taken into account. Nevertheless, the behavior can be quite different at room temperature, or at elevated temperature, because the fluctuations in the atomic positions cause shifts in the electronic energy bands. We carried out a series of calculations showing that, in fact, such shifts can change a topological material into a normal one, or vice versa, under certain conditions.

Broader impacts. Under this project, we have developed several computer code packages, mainly for analyzing the topological properties of electrons in crystalline materials, and have made these packages publicly available to the scientific community. The research has resulted in the training, mentorship, and career development of students and postdocs. Applications of the research may eventually contribute to technological advances with commercial impact.
